Social Welfare Department The Social Welfare Department of the Maharashtra Government‚Äôs Social Justice and Special Assistance Division implements various initiatives through the District Council‚Äôs Social Welfare Department to ensure equal opportunities and social justice for Scheduled Castes and other underprivileged groups in rural areas, focusing on education, economic development, and social security. This department implements various welfare schemes to uplift the Scheduled Castes and other weaker sections of society. It provides financial assistance for education, training, skill development, employment generation, housing, and other essential needs. To enhance the social and educational standards of backward classes and support their advancement, the District Councils are required to allocate at least 20% of their income towards welfare schemes for the backward classes. The implementation and supervision of these schemes are carried out through the Social Welfare Department. Schemes Implemented by the Social Welfare Department Development of Settlements of Scheduled Castes and Neo-Buddhist Communities Under the scheme for the development of settlements of Scheduled Castes and Neo-Buddhist communities, basic amenities are provided in these localities. This includes the construction of essential infrastructure such as water supply systems, internal roads, drainage systems, paved blocks, streetlights, and community halls. Depending on the population of the settlement, financial aid ranging from ‚Çπ4 lakh to ‚Çπ40 lakh is allocated for these developmental activities. Inter-Caste Marriage Incentive Grant Scheme The primary objective of the Social Welfare Department‚Äôs Inter-Caste Marriage Incentive Scheme is to reduce caste-based discrimination and promote social unity and harmony. Under this scheme, if one partner belongs to the Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, Denotified Tribes (Vimukta Jati), Nomadic Tribes, and the other partner belongs to the upper-caste Hindu, Lingayat, Jain, or Sikh communities, the marriage is considered inter-caste. Additionally, marriages between different subgroups within Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, Denotified Tribes (Vimukta Jati), and Nomadic Tribes are also recognized as inter-caste marriages. This scheme is designed to foster social cohesion and help integrate individuals from Scheduled Castes and Tribes into mainstream society. As part of the initiative, the government provides financial assistance of ‚Çπ50,000 to couples who enter into inter-caste marriages. Assistance Grant for Subsidized Hostels for Backward Classes The primary objective of this scheme is to provide educational opportunities to economically weaker students belonging to Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, Other Backward Classes, Denotified Tribes (Vimukta Jati), Nomadic Tribes, and Special Backward Classes. The scheme ensures the provision of accommodation, food, and basic amenities to maintain continuity in education, reduce dropout rates, and promote social and economic upliftment. Under the jurisdiction of the District Council, Pune, a total of 82 subsidized hostels are currently operational. Pre-Matric Scholarship Scheme The primary objective of this scheme is to provide financial assistance to students from Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, Other Backward Classes, Denotified Tribes (Vimukta Jati), and Special Backward Classes studying in grades 5 to 10. It aims to encourage them to continue their schooling, reduce dropout rates, provide equal educational opportunities, and contribute to their socio-economic upliftment. The scholarship amount is directly deposited into the students‚Äô bank accounts to ease their financial burden and help cover educational expenses. Under this scheme, the following scholarships are provided: Savitribai Phule Scholarship Scheme Government of India Pre-Matric Scholarship for Scheduled Caste Students in Grades 9 and 10 Pre-Matric Scholarship for Children of Parents Engaged in Unclean Occupations, Including Waste Collecting Educational and Examination Fee Assistance for Backward Class Students Merit-Based Scholarship for Secondary School Students. Earn and Learn‚Äù Scheme Under the District Council‚Äôs 20% Cess Fund, the Social Welfare Department implements the ‚ÄúEarn and Learn‚Äù Scheme to support financially weaker and aspiring students. The primary aim of this scheme is to provide students with part-time job opportunities at educational institutions or other locations to help them cover their educational expenses. This initiative promotes self-reliance, enhances education and skill development, and reduces dropout rates among students facing financial challenges during higher education. By assisting students in overcoming financial barriers, the scheme fosters confidence and independence. The program is funded through the District Council‚Äôs 20% Cess Fund, ensuring direct support for students in need. Internship Program for BBA Students through MKCL Under this scheme, BBA students enrolled through MKCL are appointed as interns in various departments of the District Council to gain hands-on experience in administrative work. These students receive a stipend ranging from ‚Çπ12,000 to ‚Çπ14,000 per month. Divyang Housing Scheme This initiative aims to provide secure, dignified, and stable housing to economically weaker and homeless individuals with disabilities. The scheme focuses on improving their standard of living, fostering social and economic empowerment, increasing self-reliance, ensuring access to basic amenities, and creating inclusive development opportunities. It also promotes rehabilitation, helping beneficiaries lead independent lives. Under this scheme, eligible beneficiaries receive an incentive grant of ‚Çπ1,20,000 through the Pune District Council. Yashwant Housing Scheme This scheme supports economically weaker and homeless beneficiaries belonging to Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, Denotified Tribes (Vimukta Jati), and Nomadic Tribes by providing safe, dignified, and stable housing. The goal is to promote social and economic upliftment, offer liveable spaces with basic amenities, contribute to poverty eradication, and improve their quality of life while ensuring social harmony and inclusive development. Through this scheme, eligible beneficiaries receive an incentive grant of ‚Çπ1,20,000 from the Pune District Council. From Community Centres to Knowledge Hubs Initiative This scheme aims to develop community centres in rural areas into comprehensive knowledge hubs for educational, social, and cultural activities. It ensures access to libraries, study rooms, and digital learning facilities for students and citizens, enabling skill development training and educational empowerment for disadvantaged groups. The initiative promotes knowledge-based societal growth and enhances community learning resources. Under this scheme, 596 community centres within the Pune District Council are being upgraded, receiving uniform renovations, library resources, computers, and other facilities to support learning and development. Provision of Livelihood Allowance Grant for Severely Disabled Individuals The primary objective of this scheme is to provide monthly financial assistance to individuals with more than 60% disability to help them overcome economic instability, meet basic needs, and support medical and daily expenses. The scheme ensures social and economic security, allowing them to live dignified lives, and aims to improve their standard of living by offering necessary aid for self-reliance. Under this scheme, 9,205 eligible beneficiaries in the Pune District Council receive an annual livelihood allowance of ‚Çπ6,000. Telephone : 020-26131774 Address : District Level Office
Social Welfare Department
Social Welfare Department
Social Welfare Department
Social Welfare Department
The Social Welfare Department of the Maharashtra Government‚Äôs Social Justice and Special Assistance Division implements various initiatives through the District Council‚Äôs Social Welfare Department to ensure equal opportunities and social justice for Scheduled Castes and other underprivileged groups in rural areas, focusing on education, economic development, and social security. This department implements various welfare schemes to uplift the Scheduled Castes and other weaker sections of society. It provides financial assistance for education, training, skill development, employment generation, housing, and other essential needs. To enhance the social and educational standards of backward classes and support their advancement, the District Councils are required to allocate at least 20% of their income towards welfare schemes for the backward classes. The implementation and supervision of these schemes are carried out through the Social Welfare Department. Schemes Implemented by the Social Welfare Department Development of Settlements of Scheduled Castes and Neo-Buddhist Communities Under the scheme for the development of settlements of Scheduled Castes and Neo-Buddhist communities, basic amenities are provided in these localities. This includes the construction of essential infrastructure such as water supply systems, internal roads, drainage systems, paved blocks, streetlights, and community halls. Depending on the population of the settlement, financial aid ranging from ‚Çπ4 lakh to ‚Çπ40 lakh is allocated for these developmental activities. Inter-Caste Marriage Incentive Grant Scheme The primary objective of the Social Welfare Department‚Äôs Inter-Caste Marriage Incentive Scheme is to reduce caste-based discrimination and promote social unity and harmony. Under this scheme, if one partner belongs to the Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, Denotified Tribes (Vimukta Jati), Nomadic Tribes, and the other partner belongs to the upper-caste Hindu, Lingayat, Jain, or Sikh communities, the marriage is considered inter-caste. Additionally, marriages between different subgroups within Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, Denotified Tribes (Vimukta Jati), and Nomadic Tribes are also recognized as inter-caste marriages. This scheme is designed to foster social cohesion and help integrate individuals from Scheduled Castes and Tribes into mainstream society. As part of the initiative, the government provides financial assistance of ‚Çπ50,000 to couples who enter into inter-caste marriages. Assistance Grant for Subsidized Hostels for Backward Classes The primary objective of this scheme is to provide educational opportunities to economically weaker students belonging to Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, Other Backward Classes, Denotified Tribes (Vimukta Jati), Nomadic Tribes, and Special Backward Classes. The scheme ensures the provision of accommodation, food, and basic amenities to maintain continuity in education, reduce dropout rates, and promote social and economic upliftment. Under the jurisdiction of the District Council, Pune, a total of 82 subsidized hostels are currently operational. Pre-Matric Scholarship Scheme The primary objective of this scheme is to provide financial assistance to students from Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, Other Backward Classes, Denotified Tribes (Vimukta Jati), and Special Backward Classes studying in grades 5 to 10. It aims to encourage them to continue their schooling, reduce dropout rates, provide equal educational opportunities, and contribute to their socio-economic upliftment. The scholarship amount is directly deposited into the students‚Äô bank accounts to ease their financial burden and help cover educational expenses. Under this scheme, the following scholarships are provided: Savitribai Phule Scholarship Scheme Government of India Pre-Matric Scholarship for Scheduled Caste Students in Grades 9 and 10 Pre-Matric Scholarship for Children of Parents Engaged in Unclean Occupations, Including Waste Collecting Educational and Examination Fee Assistance for Backward Class Students Merit-Based Scholarship for Secondary School Students. Earn and Learn‚Äù Scheme Under the District Council‚Äôs 20% Cess Fund, the Social Welfare Department implements the ‚ÄúEarn and Learn‚Äù Scheme to support financially weaker and aspiring students. The primary aim of this scheme is to provide students with part-time job opportunities at educational institutions or other locations to help them cover their educational expenses. This initiative promotes self-reliance, enhances education and skill development, and reduces dropout rates among students facing financial challenges during higher education. By assisting students in overcoming financial barriers, the scheme fosters confidence and independence. The program is funded through the District Council‚Äôs 20% Cess Fund, ensuring direct support for students in need. Internship Program for BBA Students through MKCL Under this scheme, BBA students enrolled through MKCL are appointed as interns in various departments of the District Council to gain hands-on experience in administrative work. These students receive a stipend ranging from ‚Çπ12,000 to ‚Çπ14,000 per month. Divyang Housing Scheme This initiative aims to provide secure, dignified, and stable housing to economically weaker and homeless individuals with disabilities. The scheme focuses on improving their standard of living, fostering social and economic empowerment, increasing self-reliance, ensuring access to basic amenities, and creating inclusive development opportunities. It also promotes rehabilitation, helping beneficiaries lead independent lives. Under this scheme, eligible beneficiaries receive an incentive grant of ‚Çπ1,20,000 through the Pune District Council. Yashwant Housing Scheme This scheme supports economically weaker and homeless beneficiaries belonging to Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, Denotified Tribes (Vimukta Jati), and Nomadic Tribes by providing safe, dignified, and stable housing. The goal is to promote social and economic upliftment, offer liveable spaces with basic amenities, contribute to poverty eradication, and improve their quality of life while ensuring social harmony and inclusive development. Through this scheme, eligible beneficiaries receive an incentive grant of ‚Çπ1,20,000 from the Pune District Council. From Community Centres to Knowledge Hubs Initiative This scheme aims to develop community centres in rural areas into comprehensive knowledge hubs for educational, social, and cultural activities. It ensures access to libraries, study rooms, and digital learning facilities for students and citizens, enabling skill development training and educational empowerment for disadvantaged groups. The initiative promotes knowledge-based societal growth and enhances community learning resources. Under this scheme, 596 community centres within the Pune District Council are being upgraded, receiving uniform renovations, library resources, computers, and other facilities to support learning and development. Provision of Livelihood Allowance Grant for Severely Disabled Individuals The primary objective of this scheme is to provide monthly financial assistance to individuals with more than 60% disability to help them overcome economic instability, meet basic needs, and support medical and daily expenses. The scheme ensures social and economic security, allowing them to live dignified lives, and aims to improve their standard of living by offering necessary aid for self-reliance. Under this scheme, 9,205 eligible beneficiaries in the Pune District Council receive an annual livelihood allowance of ‚Çπ6,000. Telephone : 020-26131774 Address : District Level Office
The Social Welfare Department of the Maharashtra Government‚Äôs Social Justice and Special Assistance Division implements various initiatives through the District Council‚Äôs Social Welfare Department to ensure equal opportunities and social justice for Scheduled Castes and other underprivileged groups in rural areas, focusing on education, economic development, and social security. This department implements various welfare schemes to uplift the Scheduled Castes and other weaker sections of society. It provides financial assistance for education, training, skill development, employment generation, housing, and other essential needs.
To enhance the social and educational standards of backward classes and support their advancement, the District Councils are required to allocate at least 20% of their income towards welfare schemes for the backward classes. The implementation and supervision of these schemes are carried out through the Social Welfare Department.
Schemes Implemented by the Social Welfare Department
Development of Settlements of Scheduled Castes and Neo-Buddhist Communities Under the scheme for the development of settlements of Scheduled Castes and Neo-Buddhist communities, basic amenities are provided in these localities. This includes the construction of essential infrastructure such as water supply systems, internal roads, drainage systems, paved blocks, streetlights, and community halls. Depending on the population of the settlement, financial aid ranging from ‚Çπ4 lakh to ‚Çπ40 lakh is allocated for these developmental activities.
Inter-Caste Marriage Incentive Grant Scheme
The primary objective of the Social Welfare Department‚Äôs Inter-Caste Marriage Incentive Scheme is to reduce caste-based discrimination and promote social unity and harmony. Under this scheme, if one partner belongs to the Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, Denotified Tribes (Vimukta Jati), Nomadic Tribes, and the other partner belongs to the upper-caste Hindu, Lingayat, Jain, or Sikh communities, the marriage is considered inter-caste. Additionally, marriages between different subgroups within Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, Denotified Tribes (Vimukta Jati), and Nomadic Tribes are also recognized as inter-caste marriages. This scheme is designed to foster social cohesion and help integrate individuals from Scheduled Castes and Tribes into mainstream society. As part of the initiative, the government provides financial assistance of ‚Çπ50,000 to couples who enter into inter-caste marriages.
Assistance Grant for Subsidized Hostels for Backward Classes
The primary objective of this scheme is to provide educational opportunities to economically weaker students belonging to Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, Other Backward Classes, Denotified Tribes (Vimukta Jati), Nomadic Tribes, and Special Backward Classes. The scheme ensures the provision of accommodation, food, and basic amenities to maintain continuity in education, reduce dropout rates, and promote social and economic upliftment. Under the jurisdiction of the District Council, Pune, a total of 82 subsidized hostels are currently operational.
Pre-Matric Scholarship Scheme
The primary objective of this scheme is to provide financial assistance to students from Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, Other Backward Classes, Denotified Tribes (Vimukta Jati), and Special Backward Classes studying in grades 5 to 10. It aims to encourage them to continue their schooling, reduce dropout rates, provide equal educational opportunities, and contribute to their socio-economic upliftment. The scholarship amount is directly deposited into the students‚Äô bank accounts to ease their financial burden and help cover educational expenses.
Under this scheme, the following scholarships are provided:
Savitribai Phule Scholarship Scheme
Government of India Pre-Matric Scholarship for Scheduled Caste Students in Grades 9 and 10
Pre-Matric Scholarship for Children of Parents Engaged in Unclean Occupations, Including Waste Collecting
Educational and Examination Fee Assistance for Backward Class Students
Merit-Based Scholarship for Secondary School Students.
Earn and Learn‚Äù Scheme
Under the District Council‚Äôs 20% Cess Fund, the Social Welfare Department implements the ‚ÄúEarn and Learn‚Äù Scheme to support financially weaker and aspiring students. The primary aim of this scheme is to provide students with part-time job opportunities at educational institutions or other locations to help them cover their educational expenses.
This initiative promotes self-reliance, enhances education and skill development, and reduces dropout rates among students facing financial challenges during higher education. By assisting students in overcoming financial barriers, the scheme fosters confidence and independence.
The program is funded through the District Council‚Äôs 20% Cess Fund, ensuring direct support for students in need.
Internship Program for BBA Students through MKCL
Under this scheme, BBA students enrolled through MKCL are appointed as interns in various departments of the District Council to gain hands-on experience in administrative work. These students receive a stipend ranging from ‚Çπ12,000 to ‚Çπ14,000 per month.
Divyang Housing Scheme
This initiative aims to provide secure, dignified, and stable housing to economically weaker and homeless individuals with disabilities. The scheme focuses on improving their standard of living, fostering social and economic empowerment, increasing self-reliance, ensuring access to basic amenities, and creating inclusive development opportunities. It also promotes rehabilitation, helping beneficiaries lead independent lives.
Under this scheme, eligible beneficiaries receive an incentive grant of ‚Çπ1,20,000 through the Pune District Council.
Yashwant Housing Scheme
This scheme supports economically weaker and homeless beneficiaries belonging to Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, Denotified Tribes (Vimukta Jati), and Nomadic Tribes by providing safe, dignified, and stable housing. The goal is to promote social and economic upliftment, offer liveable spaces with basic amenities, contribute to poverty eradication, and improve their quality of life while ensuring social harmony and inclusive development.
Through this scheme, eligible beneficiaries receive an incentive grant of ‚Çπ1,20,000 from the Pune District Council.
From Community Centres to Knowledge Hubs Initiative
This scheme aims to develop community centres in rural areas into comprehensive knowledge hubs for educational, social, and cultural activities. It ensures access to libraries, study rooms, and digital learning facilities for students and citizens, enabling skill development training and educational empowerment for disadvantaged groups. The initiative promotes knowledge-based societal growth and enhances community learning resources.
Under this scheme, 596 community centres within the Pune District Council are being upgraded, receiving uniform renovations, library resources, computers, and other facilities to support learning and development.
Provision of Livelihood Allowance Grant for Severely Disabled Individuals
The primary objective of this scheme is to provide monthly financial assistance to individuals with more than 60% disability to help them overcome economic instability, meet basic needs, and support medical and daily expenses. The scheme ensures social and economic security, allowing them to live dignified lives, and aims to improve their standard of living by offering necessary aid for self-reliance. Under this scheme, 9,205 eligible beneficiaries in the Pune District Council receive an annual livelihood allowance of ‚Çπ6,000.
Telephone : 020-26131774
Address : District Level Office

‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§† ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§†‡§æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡§® ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ( ‡§≤ ‚Äå.‡§™‡§æ ) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ/‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•á / ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á ‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§®‡§¶ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä, ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´-‡•®‡•¨ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•â‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§∞ ‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï (‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏/ ‡§è‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏ / ‡§è‡§è‡§∏ ) ‡§ë‡§®‡§≤‡§æ‡§à‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ü‡§≤ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§π‡§ï‡•ç‚Äç‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ
‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§† ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§†‡§æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡§® ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ( ‡§≤ ‚Äå.‡§™‡§æ ) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ/‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•á / ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á ‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§®‡§¶ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä, ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´-‡•®‡•¨ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•â‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§∞ ‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï (‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏/ ‡§è‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏ / ‡§è‡§è‡§∏ ) ‡§ë‡§®‡§≤‡§æ‡§à‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ü‡§≤ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§π‡§ï‡•ç‚Äç‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§†
‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ
‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä
‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø
‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ
‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§†‡§æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡§® ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ( ‡§≤ ‚Äå.‡§™‡§æ ) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£

‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ( ‡§≤ ‚Äå.‡§™‡§æ ) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó

‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•á / ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á ‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§®‡§¶ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä, ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´-‡•®‡•¨ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä
‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•á / ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ

‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä, ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´
‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´-‡•®‡•¨
‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä
‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•â‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§∞ ‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§®
‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§®
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï (‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏/ ‡§è‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏ / ‡§è‡§è‡§∏ ) ‡§ë‡§®‡§≤‡§æ‡§à‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ü‡§≤
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï (‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏/ ‡§è‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏ / ‡§è‡§è‡§∏ )
‡§ë‡§®‡§≤‡§æ‡§à‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ü‡§≤
‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§π‡§ï‡•ç‚Äç‡§ï
‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ
‡§¨‡§Ç‡§¶
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§† Finance Department Print ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§´‡•á‡§∏‡§¨‡•Å‡§ï ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ü‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§°‡§á‡§®‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§† Finance Department Print ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§´‡•á‡§∏‡§¨‡•Å‡§ï ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ü‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§°‡§á‡§®‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§† Finance Department Print ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§´‡•á‡§∏‡§¨‡•Å‡§ï ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ü‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§°‡§á‡§®‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§† Finance Department

Finance Department
Print ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§´‡•á‡§∏‡§¨‡•Å‡§ï ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ü‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§°‡§á‡§®‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ
Print ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§´‡•á‡§∏‡§¨‡•Å‡§ï ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ü‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§°‡§á‡§®‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ

Print
‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ
‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ
‡§´‡•á‡§∏‡§¨‡•Å‡§ï ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ
‡§´‡•á‡§∏‡§¨‡•Å‡§ï ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ
‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ü‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ
‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ü‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ
‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§°‡§á‡§®‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ
‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§°‡§á‡§®‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ
Finance Department Introduction All financial transactions of the Zilla Parishad are handled by the Finance Department. The Head of the Finance Department in the Zilla Parishad is the Chief Accounts and Finance Officer, who is an officer of the rank of Deputy Director in the Maharashtra Finance and Accounts Service. He works as the Financial Advisor and Primary Auditor of the Zilla Parishad regarding the matters of accounts and budget estimates as well as the implementation of financial rules. He is assisted by a Dy. Chief Accounts and Finance Officer (Class 1) and three Accounts Officers (Class 2). No authority approves any financial transaction without his advice. The following work is carried out through various branches under the Finance Department. ‚Äì Establishment Branch ‚Äì handles establishment-related matters of Gazetted Officers and Accounts Cadre employees of the Finance Department. Establishment and other matters of Accounts Cadre employees (e.g. appointments, promotions, transfers, advance pay increments, seniority lists, retirement, confidential records, 54- year review, etc.) All examination-related matters of Accounts Cadre employees, retirement pay, B.I.N., group insurance, medical reimbursement proposals of officers/employees, preparation and submission for approval. Additional charge cases approval, proceedings regarding Hon. Commissioner inspection, etc. ‚Äì In the cash branch, after the approval of salary, construction/roads and other payments, their operational checks are prepared and distributed. The checks and other deposits received from the treasury are recorded in the cash book. Also, the daily/monthly deposit and expenditure records are reconciled with the bank. Store Department/Branch ‚Äì As per Rule 202 of Maharashtra Zilla Parishad and Panchayat Samiti Accounts Code 1968, the inventory of Zilla Parishad can be kept at the premises of Zilla Parishad and Panchayat Samiti. Stationery, forms and records required by all departments and Panchayat Samiti of Zilla Parishad are purchased and distributed through the Warehouse Branch. Central Audit Branch ‚Äì In the Central Audit Branch, administrative approval/expenditure approval is given on the proposals received from the Heads of Accounts in the Zilla Parishad. Also, after checking all types of payments received, remarks are recorded regarding the receipts and expenses, the monthly accounts of the headquarters are prepared by recording the receipts and expenses. Also, the entire process of planning and distributing the funds received from the 15th Finance Commission of the Central Government is done by this department. Budget and Reconcilation Branch ‚Äì As per the provisions of Maharashtra Zilla Parishad andPanchayat Samiti Act 1961, Rules 137 and 138, the original budget of the Zilla Parishad and Panchayat Samiti as well as the revised budget are prepared. The said budget is scrutinized in the Finance Committee. As recommended by the Committee, the said budget is submitted to the general meeting of the Zilla Parishad for approval. In the general meeting, the revised budget and original budget are approved by including the amendments and suggestions suggested by the Hon‚Äôble Zilla Parishad members. After the approval of the budget of the Zilla Parishad, the approved funds are distributed to the concerned department. The Compilation branch ‚Äì prepares the monthly accounts of the Zilla Parishad by collecting the accounts of receipts and expenditure of all the Panchayat Samiti and the headquarters in the district. The monthly accounts are placed before the Standing Committee for final approval after the approval of the Finance Committee every month. The monthly accounts are reconciled with the monthly accounts by the concerned department. The annual accounts of the Zilla Parishad are prepared from the monthly accounts. After the scrutiny of the said annual accounts in the Finance Committee meeting, they are submitted for the approval of the Zilla Parishad general meeting before September. After the approval of the Zilla Parishad meeting, the said accounts are published in the Government Gazette before 15 November. Provident Fund Branch ‚Äì The Provident Fund accounts of all the non-teaching class 3 and class 4 employees of the Zilla Parishad are maintained by the Finance Department. A computerized system is used to maintain these accounts. After receiving the proposal for refund/non-refund of the Provident Fund and final payment, the action is taken to receive the cheque from the treasury immediately. Also, the benefit of the deposit-linked scheme is paid immediately to the heirs of the employees who died while in the Zilla Parishad service. The group insurance amount is paid to the concerned employees. External Audit Branch ‚Äì Ministry of Rural Development and Water Conservation, Government of Maharashtra, Mumbai, vide reference no. APT/ 1092/ CR/ 76613 dated 7/10/1997, Internal Audit Teams have been formed at the district level for the audit of accounts of Zilla Parishad and Panchayat Samiti. The internal audit of the accounts of the Head of Accounts and Panchayat Samiti for the completed financial year is conducted through this team. Coordination and guidance is provided for the resolution of the audit objections from the Local Fund Accounts, Panchayat Raj Samiti and the Accountant General‚Äôs Office. The revised salary determination of Zilla Parishad employees as per the Pay Commission is verified through this department. Pension Branch:- Under the Maharashtra Civil Services (Pension) Rules, 1982, the retirement pay is sanctioned after scrutinizing the cases of employees of Zilla Parishad who retire after completing 58 years of age in case of Class 3 and 60 years in case of Class 4 and also after completing other retirements. There are 8991 teachers‚Äô pension holders and 4473 non- teaching pension holders under Pune Zilla Parishad. The Finance Department ensures that the said pension holders are paid monthly pension within the prescribed period. The following fund-wise accounts are maintained in the Finance Department. ‚Ä¢ Zilla Parishad Scheme -(District Fund) ‚Ä¢ Agency Scheme (Agency Fund) ‚Ä¢ Transferred Scheme (Government Fund) ‚Ä¢ Repair and maintenance fund ‚Ä¢ Depreciation fund
Finance Department
Finance Department
Finance Department
Finance Department
Introduction All financial transactions of the Zilla Parishad are handled by the Finance Department. The Head of the Finance Department in the Zilla Parishad is the Chief Accounts and Finance Officer, who is an officer of the rank of Deputy Director in the Maharashtra Finance and Accounts Service. He works as the Financial Advisor and Primary Auditor of the Zilla Parishad regarding the matters of accounts and budget estimates as well as the implementation of financial rules. He is assisted by a Dy. Chief Accounts and Finance Officer (Class 1) and three Accounts Officers (Class 2). No authority approves any financial transaction without his advice. The following work is carried out through various branches under the Finance Department. ‚Äì Establishment Branch ‚Äì handles establishment-related matters of Gazetted Officers and Accounts Cadre employees of the Finance Department. Establishment and other matters of Accounts Cadre employees (e.g. appointments, promotions, transfers, advance pay increments, seniority lists, retirement, confidential records, 54- year review, etc.) All examination-related matters of Accounts Cadre employees, retirement pay, B.I.N., group insurance, medical reimbursement proposals of officers/employees, preparation and submission for approval. Additional charge cases approval, proceedings regarding Hon. Commissioner inspection, etc. ‚Äì In the cash branch, after the approval of salary, construction/roads and other payments, their operational checks are prepared and distributed. The checks and other deposits received from the treasury are recorded in the cash book. Also, the daily/monthly deposit and expenditure records are reconciled with the bank. Stationery, forms and records required by all departments and Panchayat Samiti of Zilla Parishad are purchased and distributed through the Warehouse Branch. Also, after checking all types of payments received, remarks are recorded regarding the receipts and expenses, the monthly accounts of the headquarters are prepared by recording the receipts and expenses. Also, the entire process of planning and distributing the funds received from the 15th Finance Commission of the Central Government is done by this department. The said budget is scrutinized in the Finance Committee. As recommended by the Committee, the said budget is submitted to the general meeting of the Zilla Parishad for approval. In the general meeting, the revised budget and original budget are approved by including the amendments and suggestions suggested by the Hon‚Äôble Zilla Parishad members. After the approval of the budget of the Zilla Parishad, the approved funds are distributed to the concerned department. The Compilation branch ‚Äì prepares the monthly accounts of the Zilla Parishad by collecting the accounts of receipts and expenditure of all the Panchayat Samiti and the headquarters in the district. The monthly accounts are placed before the Standing Committee for final approval after the approval of the Finance Committee every month. The monthly accounts are reconciled with the monthly accounts by the concerned department. The annual accounts of the Zilla Parishad are prepared from the monthly accounts. After the scrutiny of the said annual accounts in the Finance Committee meeting, they are submitted for the approval of the Zilla Parishad general meeting before September. After the approval of the Zilla Parishad meeting, the said accounts are published in the Government Gazette before 15 November. Provident Fund Branch ‚Äì The Provident Fund accounts of all the non-teaching class 3 and class 4 employees of the Zilla Parishad are maintained by the Finance Department. A computerized system is used to maintain these accounts. After receiving the proposal for refund/non-refund of the Provident Fund and final payment, the action is taken to receive the cheque from the treasury immediately. Also, the benefit of the deposit-linked scheme is paid immediately to the heirs of the employees who died while in the Zilla Parishad service. The group insurance amount is paid to the concerned employees. External Audit Branch ‚Äì Ministry of Rural Development and Water Conservation, Government of Maharashtra, Mumbai, vide reference no. APT/ 1092/ CR/ 76613 dated 7/10/1997, Internal Audit Teams have been formed at the district level for the audit of accounts of Zilla Parishad and Panchayat Samiti. The internal audit of the accounts of the Head of Accounts and Panchayat Samiti for the completed financial year is conducted through this team. Coordination and guidance is provided for the resolution of the audit objections from the Local Fund Accounts, Panchayat Raj Samiti and the Accountant General‚Äôs Office. The revised salary determination of Zilla Parishad employees as per the Pay Commission is verified through this department. Pension Branch:- Under the Maharashtra Civil Services (Pension) Rules, 1982, the retirement pay is sanctioned after scrutinizing the cases of employees of Zilla Parishad who retire after completing 58 years of age in case of Class 3 and 60 years in case of Class 4 and also after completing other retirements. There are 8991 teachers‚Äô pension holders and 4473 non- teaching pension holders under Pune Zilla Parishad. The Finance Department ensures that the said pension holders are paid monthly pension within the prescribed period. The following fund-wise accounts are maintained in the Finance Department. ‚Ä¢ Zilla Parishad Scheme -(District Fund) ‚Ä¢ Agency Scheme (Agency Fund) ‚Ä¢ Transferred Scheme (Government Fund) ‚Ä¢ Repair and maintenance fund ‚Ä¢ Depreciation fund

Useful Links
‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•á‡§¨‡§∏‡§æ‡§á‡§ü ‡§ß‡•ã‡§∞‡§£‡•á ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§§ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¨ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ï
‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•á‡§¨‡§∏‡§æ‡§á‡§ü ‡§ß‡•ã‡§∞‡§£‡•á ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§§ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¨ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ï
‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø

‡§Æ‡§¶‡§§
‡§µ‡•á‡§¨ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ï

TITLE: ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó | ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•á | ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§

English ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡•á ‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ó ‡§ï‡•â‡§®‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ü ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡•â‡§®‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ü ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•â‡§®‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ü ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§á‡§ü ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏ Invert Saturation ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•Ç‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§´‡•â‡§®‡•ç‡§ü ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¢‡§µ‡§æ ‡§´‡•â‡§®‡•ç‡§ü ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§´‡•â‡§®‡•ç‡§ü ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•Ç‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•á‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§â‡§Ç‡§ö‡•Ä Others Hide Images Big Cursor ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§® Government of Maharashtra

‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§†‡§æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡§® ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ( ‡§≤ ‚Äå.‡§™‡§æ ) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ/‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•á / ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á ‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§®‡§¶ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä, ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´-‡•®‡•¨ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•â‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§∞ ‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï (‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏/ ‡§è‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏ / ‡§è‡§è‡§∏ ) ‡§ë‡§®‡§≤‡§æ‡§à‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ü‡§≤ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§π‡§ï‡•ç‚Äç‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ
‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§† ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§†‡§æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡§® ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ( ‡§≤ ‚Äå.‡§™‡§æ ) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ/‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•á / ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á ‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§®‡§¶ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä, ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´-‡•®‡•¨ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•â‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§∞ ‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï (‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏/ ‡§è‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏ / ‡§è‡§è‡§∏ ) ‡§ë‡§®‡§≤‡§æ‡§à‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ü‡§≤ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§π‡§ï‡•ç‚Äç‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§†
‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ
‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä
‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø
‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ
‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§†‡§æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡§® ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ( ‡§≤ ‚Äå.‡§™‡§æ ) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£
‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ
‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§†‡§æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£
‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞
‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£
‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡§®
‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ( ‡§≤ ‚Äå.‡§™‡§æ ) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ
‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§£
‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§£
‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ/‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§
‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞
‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§
‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•á / ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á ‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§®‡§¶ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä, ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´-‡•®‡•¨ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä
‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•á / ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ
‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á ‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ
‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§®‡§¶
‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä, ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´
‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´-‡•®‡•¨
‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä
‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•â‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§∞ ‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§®
‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§®
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï (‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏/ ‡§è‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏ / ‡§è‡§è‡§∏ ) ‡§ë‡§®‡§≤‡§æ‡§à‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ü‡§≤
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï (‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏/ ‡§è‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏ / ‡§è‡§è‡§∏ )
‡§ë‡§®‡§≤‡§æ‡§à‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ü‡§≤
‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§π‡§ï‡•ç‚Äç‡§ï
‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ
‡§¨‡§Ç‡§¶
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó Print ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§´‡•á‡§∏‡§¨‡•Å‡§ï ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ü‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§°‡§á‡§®‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó Print ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§´‡•á‡§∏‡§¨‡•Å‡§ï ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ü‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§°‡§á‡§®‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó Print ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§´‡•á‡§∏‡§¨‡•Å‡§ï ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ü‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§°‡§á‡§®‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ

‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó

‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á. ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤ 13 ‡§§‡§æ‡§≤‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ 22 ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§§ 4395 ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡§§. ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§§- ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ï ‡§™‡•ã‡§∑‡§£ ‡§Ü‡§π‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ã. ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§≤‡§∏‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á. ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§£‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á. ‡§Ü‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§≤‡•á‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á. ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§π‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§µ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§¶‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á. ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•å‡§™‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§¶‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á. ‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≥‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§®‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ï‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§µ‡§æ. ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‚Äì ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§ :‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§®‡§∏‡•á‡§≤ ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§ó‡§ü ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§ï‡§°‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ.‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï-‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•Ç‡§® ‡§∏‡§¶‡§∞‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å‡§® ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á. ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‚Äì ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ 10 ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§ú‡•Å‡§®‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§µ ‡§∏‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞‡§ï‡•ã‡§≥ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ó‡§ü ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•á ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§ú‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡§π ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§ï‡§°‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ.‡§∏‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï-‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•Ç‡§® ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§§. ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§π‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ 2015 ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§§ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ ‡§ï‡§°‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•á‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ë‡§®‡§≤‡§æ‡§à‡§® ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§§‡§™‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•Ä : 020-26054299 ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ : ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡•á
‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á. ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤ 13 ‡§§‡§æ‡§≤‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ 22 ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§§ 4395 ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡§§.
‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§§-
‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ï ‡§™‡•ã‡§∑‡§£ ‡§Ü‡§π‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ã.
‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§≤‡§∏‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á.
‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§£‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á.
‡§Ü‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§≤‡•á‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á.
‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§π‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§µ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§¶‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á.
‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•å‡§™‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§¶‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á.
‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≥‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§®‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ï‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§µ‡§æ.
‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‚Äì ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§ :‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§®‡§∏‡•á‡§≤ ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§ó‡§ü ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§ï‡§°‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ.‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï-‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•Ç‡§® ‡§∏‡§¶‡§∞‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å‡§® ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á.
‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‚Äì ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ 10 ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§ú‡•Å‡§®‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§µ ‡§∏‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞‡§ï‡•ã‡§≥ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ó‡§ü ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•á ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§ú‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡§π ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§ï‡§°‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ.‡§∏‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï-‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•Ç‡§® ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§§.
‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§π‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ 2015 ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§§ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ ‡§ï‡§°‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•á‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ë‡§®‡§≤‡§æ‡§à‡§® ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§§‡§™‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤

Useful Links ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•á‡§¨‡§∏‡§æ‡§á‡§ü ‡§ß‡•ã‡§∞‡§£‡•á ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§§ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¨ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•á Developed and hosted by National Informatics Centre, Ministry of Electronics & Information Technology, Government of India ‡§∂‡•á‡§µ‡§ü‡§ö‡•á ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§: May 19, 2025 Download App

Women and Child Welfare Department

Women and Child Welfare Department Integrated Child Development Service Scheme is a centrally sponsored scheme.4395 Anganwadi Centers are functioning under 22 projects in 13 talukas of the district. 1. The following six services are provided to the beneficiaries of the Anganwadi Centers of the Integrated Child Development Service Scheme. i. Supplementary nutritional food is provided to the beneficiaries of the Anganwadi Centers. ii. Vaccination of children in Anganwadi is done. iii. Health check-up of children in Anganwadi is done. iv. Referral health services are provided to sick children. v. Nutrition and health education is provided to children in Anganwadi and beneficiaries. vi. Informal pre-school education is provided to children in Anganwadi. To get the above services, contact the nearest Anganwadi Center in your area. 2. Anganwadi building construction ‚ÄìIf the Anganwadi center does not have its own building, the proposal for such Anganwadi centers should be submitted to the Women and Child Welfare Department in the prescribed format with the signature of the Block Development Officer. The construction of the Anganwadi building is done after approving the said works from the District Annual General Plan of DPC. 3. Anganwadi building repair ‚ÄìIf the Anganwadi building is 10 years old and the said building needs minor repairs, the proposal should be submitted to the Women and Child Welfare Department in the prescribed format with the signature of the Block Development Officer along with the budget. The said repair works are done after approving the said works from the District Annual General Plan of DPC. Details of online services notified by the Department of Women and Child Welfare under the Right to Public Services Act 2015 Telephone : 020-26054299 Address : District Level Office
Women and Child Welfare Department
Women and Child Welfare Department
Women and Child Welfare Department
Women and Child Welfare Department
Integrated Child Development Service Scheme is a centrally sponsored scheme.4395 Anganwadi Centers are functioning under 22 projects in 13 talukas of the district. 1. The following six services are provided to the beneficiaries of the Anganwadi Centers of the Integrated Child Development Service Scheme. i. Supplementary nutritional food is provided to the beneficiaries of the Anganwadi Centers. ii. Vaccination of children in Anganwadi is done. iii. Health check-up of children in Anganwadi is done. iv. Referral health services are provided to sick children. v. Nutrition and health education is provided to children in Anganwadi and beneficiaries. vi. Informal pre-school education is provided to children in Anganwadi. To get the above services, contact the nearest Anganwadi Center in your area. 2. Anganwadi building construction ‚ÄìIf the Anganwadi center does not have its own building, the proposal for such Anganwadi centers should be submitted to the Women and Child Welfare Department in the prescribed format with the signature of the Block Development Officer. The construction of the Anganwadi building is done after approving the said works from the District Annual General Plan of DPC. 3. Anganwadi building repair ‚ÄìIf the Anganwadi building is 10 years old and the said building needs minor repairs, the proposal should be submitted to the Women and Child Welfare Department in the prescribed format with the signature of the Block Development Officer along with the budget. The said repair works are done after approving the said works from the District Annual General Plan of DPC. Details of online services notified by the Department of Women and Child Welfare under the Right to Public Services Act 2015 Telephone : 020-26054299 Address : District Level Office
Integrated Child Development Service Scheme is a centrally sponsored scheme.4395 Anganwadi Centers are functioning under 22 projects in 13 talukas of the district.
1. The following six services are provided to the beneficiaries of the Anganwadi Centers of the Integrated Child Development Service Scheme.
2. Anganwadi building construction ‚ÄìIf the Anganwadi center does not have its own building, the proposal for such Anganwadi centers should be submitted to the Women and Child Welfare Department in the prescribed format with the signature of the Block Development Officer. The construction of the Anganwadi building is done after approving the said works from the District Annual General Plan of DPC.
3. Anganwadi building repair ‚ÄìIf the Anganwadi building is 10 years old and the said building needs minor repairs, the proposal should be submitted to the Women and Child Welfare Department in the prescribed format with the signature of the Block Development Officer along with the budget. The said repair works are done after approving the said works from the District Annual General Plan of DPC.
Details of online services notified by the Department of Women and Child Welfare under the Right to Public Services Act 2015
Telephone : 020-26054299
Address : District Level Office

TITLE: Department of Social Welfare | ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•á | ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§

English ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡•á ‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ó ‡§ï‡•â‡§®‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ü ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡•â‡§®‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ü ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•â‡§®‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ü ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§á‡§ü ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏ Invert Saturation ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•Ç‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§´‡•â‡§®‡•ç‡§ü ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¢‡§µ‡§æ ‡§´‡•â‡§®‡•ç‡§ü ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§´‡•â‡§®‡•ç‡§ü ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•Ç‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•á‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§â‡§Ç‡§ö‡•Ä Others Hide Images Big Cursor ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§® Government of Maharashtra

‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§†‡§æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡§® ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ( ‡§≤ ‚Äå.‡§™‡§æ ) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ/‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•á / ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á ‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§®‡§¶ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä, ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´-‡•®‡•¨ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•â‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§∞ ‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï (‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏/ ‡§è‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏ / ‡§è‡§è‡§∏ ) ‡§ë‡§®‡§≤‡§æ‡§à‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ü‡§≤ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§π‡§ï‡•ç‚Äç‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ
‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§† ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§†‡§æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡§® ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ( ‡§≤ ‚Äå.‡§™‡§æ ) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ/‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•á / ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á ‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§®‡§¶ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä, ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´-‡•®‡•¨ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•â‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§∞ ‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï (‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏/ ‡§è‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏ / ‡§è‡§è‡§∏ ) ‡§ë‡§®‡§≤‡§æ‡§à‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ü‡§≤ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§π‡§ï‡•ç‚Äç‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§†
‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ
‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä
‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø
‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ
‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§†‡§æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡§® ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ( ‡§≤ ‚Äå.‡§™‡§æ ) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£
‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ
‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§†‡§æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£
‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞
‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‚Äì ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£
‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡§®
‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ( ‡§≤ ‚Äå.‡§™‡§æ ) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó
‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ
‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§£
‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§£
‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ/‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§
‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞
‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§
‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•á / ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á ‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§®‡§¶ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä, ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´-‡•®‡•¨ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä
‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•á / ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ
‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á ‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ
‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§®‡§¶
‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä, ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´
‡§ú‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡•®‡•¶‡•®‡•´-‡•®‡•¨
‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä
‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•â‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§∞ ‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§®
‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§®
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï (‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏/ ‡§è‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏ / ‡§è‡§è‡§∏ ) ‡§ë‡§®‡§≤‡§æ‡§à‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ü‡§≤
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï (‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏/ ‡§è‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§à‡§ì‡§∏ / ‡§è‡§è‡§∏ )
‡§ë‡§®‡§≤‡§æ‡§à‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ü‡§≤
‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§π‡§ï‡•ç‚Äç‡§ï

‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§† Department of Social Welfare Print ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§´‡•á‡§∏‡§¨‡•Å‡§ï ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ü‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§°‡§á‡§®‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§† Department of Social Welfare Print ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§´‡•á‡§∏‡§¨‡•Å‡§ï ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ü‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§°‡§á‡§®‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§† Department of Social Welfare Print ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§´‡•á‡§∏‡§¨‡•Å‡§ï ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ü‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§°‡§á‡§®‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§† Department of Social Welfare
